author: Hennessy
title: The impact of information on animal product consumption
brief_description: factual leaflets modeled after those used by animal advocacy organizations worldwide
outcome: Belief in Animal Mind Questionnaire -- I believe it’s important to treat cows humanely
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Aldoh
title: Shifting norms, static behaviour: effects of dynamic norms on meat consumption
brief_description: combination of a dynamic norm appeal (“More and more people in the UK are changing. In 2020, 33% of British people—a figure increasing every year over the previous 5 years—successfully engaged in one or more of the following behaviours to eat less meat" (and then some behaviors) and a graph showing that number going up over time
outcome: “My attitude towards eating less meat is…” adapted from Fishbein and Ajzen (2010) on a slider scale of 0 (extremely" unfavourable) to 100 (extremely favourable).
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Aldoh
title: Shifting norms, static behaviour: effects of dynamic norms on meat consumption
brief_description: dynamic norm appeal ("More and more people in the UK are changing. In 2020, 33% of British people—a figure increasing every year over the previous 5 years—successfully engaged in one or more of the following behaviours to eat less meat" and then some behaviors)
outcome: “My attitude towards eating less meat is…” adapted from Fishbein and Ajzen (2010) on a slider scale of 0 (extremely" unfavourable) to 100 (extremely favourable).
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Aldoh
title: Shifting norms, static behaviour: effects of dynamic norms on meat consumption
brief_description: a static norm message saying "In 2020, 33% of British people—roughly the same figure as in the previous 5 years—successfully engaged in one or more of the following behaviours to eat less meat" (and then some behaviors) and a graph showing that number staying static over time
outcome: “My attitude towards eating less meat is…” adapted from Fishbein and Ajzen (2010) on a slider scale of 0 (extremely" unfavourable) to 100 (extremely favourable).
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Aldoh
title: Shifting norms, static behaviour: effects of dynamic norms on meat consumption
brief_description: a static norm message saying "In 2020, 33% of British people—roughly the same figure as in the previous 5 years—successfully engaged in one or more of the following behaviours to eat less meat" (and then some behaviors)
outcome: “My attitude towards eating less meat is…” adapted from Fishbein and Ajzen (2010) on a slider scale of 0 (extremely" unfavourable) to 100 (extremely favourable).
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Anderson
title: An Experimental Investigation of the Impact of Video Media on Pork Consumption
brief_description: an evaluation of Animal Equality’s iAnimal campaign, "a virtual reality project that creates a 360-degree, immersive experience to give viewers a look into the day-to-day life of animals raised for food in factory farms and slaughterhouses"
outcome: whether participants abstain from eating pork or not
notes: "It was not a truly inactive control condition, in that the canopy used for the study was covered in graphic images of farm animals. Therefore, our ability to find differences between the control and treatment conditions may have been somewhat reduced, in that control participants essentially received a much weaker version of the manipulation." I initially had excluded this study for this reason but today I think it's estimating the effects of treatment on the motivated, which is still interesting and worth investigating. Also the study protocol on the OSF website isn't exasctly what I think of as a pre-registration but the text says they pre-registered their analyses so we'll count it

author: Anderson
title: An Experimental Investigation of the Impact of Video Media on Pork Consumption
brief_description: an evaluation of Animal Equality’s  traditional 2D video outreach
outcome: whether participants abstain from eating pork or not
notes: NA

author: Carfora (a)
title: Correlational study and randomised controlled trial for understanding and changing red meat consumption: The role of eating identities
brief_description: daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of red meat consumption
outcome: red meat consumption  (RMC)
notes: this study seems *very* similar to the other Carofa 2017 paper but I believe they're different samples & outcomes.  Another "Theory of Planned Behavior" paper. "Supplementary data related to this article can be found at http:// http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.socscimed.2017.01.005" but then there's no data

author: Carfora (a)
title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
brief_description: daily messages on the expected consequences of low red and processed meat consumption (RPMC) on health and the environment.
outcome: self-reported Red and Processed Meat Consumption
notes: "A confirmation of the effects in further studies is warranted before the findings can be generalized to all young adults." Indeed!. Also the article says "supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2019.101319" but that website says "Data not available / Data will be made available on request"

author: Carfora (a)
title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
brief_description: daily messages on the expected consequences of low red and processed meat consumption (RPMC) on the environment
outcome: self-reported Red and Processed Meat Consumption
notes: "A confirmation of the effects in further studies is warranted before the findings can be generalized to all young adults." Indeed!. Also the article says "supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2019.101319" but that website says "Data not available / Data will be made available on request"

author: Carfora (a)
title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
brief_description: daily messages on the expected consequences of low red and processed meat consumption (RPMC) on health
outcome: self-reported Red and Processed Meat Consumption
notes: "A confirmation of the effects in further studies is warranted before the findings can be generalized to all young adults." Indeed!. Also the article says "supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2019.101319" but that website says "Data not available / Data will be made available on request"

author: Carfora (b)
title: Randomised controlled trial of a text messaging intervention for reducing processed meat consumption: The mediating roles of anticipated regret and intention
brief_description: first an email about the recommended dosage of procssed meat consumption and then daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of processed meat consumption
outcome: processed meat consumption (PMC)
notes: This study is in a theoretical category of its own and we need to acknowledge that in the theoretical description. It is doing a pretty intrusive nudge in conjunction with health advice but in its own words it is doing theory of planned behaviorI suppose there is an argument for excluding this on the basis that we want to show *lasting* effects i.e. those that endure beyond treatment itself. But we included studies like this in the contact and prejudice metas and it does at least show that text messages produce more than a momentary effect

author: Carfora (b)
title: Informational and emotional daily messages to reduce red and processed meat consumption
brief_description: two weeks of messages "informing them about the health and environmental impact of excessive RPMC (e.g., “If you eat an excessive amount of red and processed meat, you will not protect your health from colon cancer, and at the same time you will not protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases”)" along with an emotional component asking them to think about their anticipated regret
outcome: food frequency questionnaire (servings of red and processed meat per week)
notes: in my humble opinion these results are not presented in the clearest manner. Group 1 had a decline of one serving on average from baseline to followup. Group 2 did not change from baseline to followup. And the control group declined by one serving. So one groups d_i_d is 1 serving and the other is -1 servings, so one positive effect and one backlash. So yes, the F test that says condition predicted results is literally correct, but were those effects in the direction expected? on average, being exposed to treatment had 0 effect. That's the takeaway of this study.

author: Carfora (b)
title: Informational and emotional daily messages to reduce red and processed meat consumption
brief_description: two weeks of messages "informing them about the health and environmental impact of excessive RPMC (e.g., “If you eat an excessive amount of red and processed meat, you will not protect your health from colon cancer, and at the same time you will not protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases”)"
outcome: food frequency questionnaire (servings of red and processed meat per week)
notes: NA

author: Delichatsios
title: Randomized Trial of a “Talking Computer” to Improve Adults' Eating Habits
brief_description: "Weekly communicationfor 6 months via a totally automated, computer-based voice system. Amongintervention group subjects, the system monitored dietary habitsand provided educational feedback, advice, and behavioral counseling. Control group subjects received physical activity promotioncounseling."
outcome: red and processed meat via PrimeScreen Instrument
notes: NA

author: Dijkstra
title: Lowering Red Meat and Processed Meat Consumption With Environmental, Animal Welfare, and Health Arguments in Italy: An Online Experiment
brief_description: text with pictures on the environmental, animal welfare, or health consequences of meat consumption
outcome: self-reported red meat consumption
notes: online study. the number of days participants eat meat was 1.78 (SD = 1.12)

author: Emmons (a)
title: Project PREVENT: A Randomized Trial to Reduce Multiple Behavioral Risk Factors for Colon Cancer
brief_description: education targeting behavioral risk factors for colorectal cancer among individuals who have been diagnosed with adenomatous colon polyps
outcome: red meat consumption (RMC)
notes: this outcome measure is pretty crude -- did a risk factor stay the same, increase, or decrease. food diary much more reliable. Also, it's borderline excludable because its methods aren't replicable -- the specific changes to the microenvironment “were not reported in detail, precluding more detailed analyses of this intervention." Alas. Noting here that it's stratified random assignment rather than cluster. Finally, this study reports costs for cost-effective estimates

author: Emmons (b)
title: Cancer Prevention Among Working Class, Multiethnic Adults: Results of the Healthy Directions–Health Centers Study
brief_description: social-contextual approach ta geting multiple levels of influence on behaviors, with special attention to low literacy skills and the shared and unique features of culture across racial/ethnic groups
outcome: red meat consumption (RMC) -- 3 or fewer servings per week
notes: Fine study; this and the other Emmons et al. 2005 paper are identified herein as "companion studies" and both are part of the " Harvard Cancer Prevention Program Project". Also provides cost-estimates for cost-effectiveness analyses. ITT also possible. Major focus is health considerd broadly, so outcomes include ceasing smoking and eating more fruits and veggies. I also might have missed the part of the study where it says how long treatment took so I am just saying it's the same as the other Emmons et al. study and treatment was 4 months and measurement was 4 months after that. protocol here https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14674737/

author: Jaacks
title: Long-term changes in dietary and food intake behaviour in the Diabetes Prevention Program Outcomes Study
brief_description: "16-session core curriculum over the first 24 weeks, followed by an individualized counselling curriculum (at least monthly contact) with the primary intervention goals of achieving and maintaining a weight loss of ≥ 7% initial body weight and a moderate intensity activity level of ≥ 150 min per week [20]. Participants were advised to reduce dietary fat gram intake to < 25% of total calories based on a calorie estimate to achieve the weight loss goal, with the addition of a calorie goal if weight loss was not achieved after the first seven sessions"
outcome: red meat servings per day
notes: NA

author: James
title: Impact of a nutrition and physical activity intervention (ENRICH: Exercise and Nutrition Routine Improving Cancer Health) on health behaviors of cancer survivors and carers: a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
intervention_condition: ENRICH: Exercise and Nutrition Routine Improving Cancer Health
brief_description: Four weekly, 2-h sessions, and two 2-h fortnightly sessions were provided (total 6 sessions) with a mix of didactic information about health and physical activity as well as some "practical activities (e.g., label reading, recipe modification, demonstration and practice of resist- ance exercises, setting step goals for the home-based walk- ing program)."
outcome: red meat (grams per day)
notes: some guesswork here (endline is how many weeks after the second forthnightly meeting?) but it's fine, we record an overall null which is consistent with the paper

author: Lee
title: Dietary and physical activity interventions for colorectal cancer survivors: a randomized controlled trial
brief_description: "Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) and the Health Action Process Approach (HAPA)" intervention with face to face conversations, phone calls, "educational pamphlets, mailed quarterly newsletters, and quarterly group meetings"
outcome: percent of people meeting the food targets for red meat reduction
notes: the DV is a binary of whether they hit specified RPM targets, and there are four groups: control, diet, diet + physical activity, and just physical activity, and the analyses combine the diet groups and the non-diet groups, which I guess is ok

author: Lindström
title: Nudging towards sustainable meat consumption: a natural field experiment
brief_description: two nudges and an appeal: colorful footsteps leading to the sustainable option, placing healthy options side by side with minced beef, and a message saying that carrots and beans are good for health, the environment, and animals
outcome: kilograms of minced beef sold per week
notes: statistical issue: there's no reporting on spread, just multivariate regression results. I'm also seeing that four stores dropped out/weren't implementing the nudges, so how we end up with 11 in each group, I am not sure. How does a control store not implement control?  As to the overall results, "the results from the regression analysis showed that none of the models explaining minced beef consumption (model. 1, 4, 5 and 8) proved enough statistical evidence to reject the null-hypothesis 1; that the nudge-intervention had no effect on consumption in treatment group."

author: Perino
title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: a quote from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (interspecies benefits).
outcome: binary variable for whether their surveyed meal contained red meat or not
notes: NA

author: Perino
title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: a quote from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (environmental benefits).
outcome: binary variable for whether their surveyed meal contained red meat or not
notes: NA

author: Perino
title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: a quote from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (personal health).
outcome: binary variable for whether their surveyed meal contained red meat or not
notes: NA

author: Schatzkin
title: Lack of Effect of a Low-Fat, High-Fiber Diet on the Recurrence of Colorectal Adenoma
brief_description: Low-Fat, High-Fiber Diet for adults with histologically confirmed colorectal adenomas delivered via "more than 50 hours of" intensive counseling involving "nutritional information and behavior-modification techniques" delivered over four years, "including 20 hours in the first year"
outcome: red and processed meat (grams per day)
notes: a little bit of guesswork on the Ns, and therefore on the standard errors. They say that a randomly selected 20% filled out the food surveys but the Ns in the table don't reflect that. But I'm assuming that they should so the Ns do. Likewise, we don't get SD but we do get SE and I multiply the SE of the control group by sqrt(n_c)

author: Sorensen
title: Promoting Behavior Change Among Working-Class, Multiethnic Workers: Results of the Healthy Directions–Small Business Study
intervention_condition: cancer prevention intervention designed to prompote healthy behaviors
brief_description: "integrated interventions focused on nutrition, physical activity, and occupational health and activities focused on individual risk factors"
outcome: </= 3 servings of red meat per week
notes: nice study; finds very little. Authors self-report it did not achieve statistical significance (the multivitamin effect was significant but there are a lot of tests being run here.) for this outcome p = .72

author: Wolstenholme
title: Two Birds, One Stone: The Effectiveness of Health and Environmental Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption and Encourage Pro-environmental Behavioral Spillover
brief_description: daily message via automated private chat on Facebook Messenger about health reasons to eat less RPM
outcome: 15-point response scale from 0 to 14 servings or more of red and processed meat (separately)
notes: NA

author: Wolstenholme
title: Two Birds, One Stone: The Effectiveness of Health and Environmental Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption and Encourage Pro-environmental Behavioral Spillover
brief_description: daily message via automated private chat on Facebook Messenger about environmental reasons to eat less RPM, e.g. "If you eat only a small amount of red and processed meat, you will protect the environment by reducing excessive land use. Remember to try and eat no more than two portions of red and processed meat this week. Please record all of the food you have eaten today using today’s food diary."
outcome: 15-point response scale from 0 to 14 servings or more of red and processed meat (separately)
notes: NA

author: Wolstenholme
title: Two Birds, One Stone: The Effectiveness of Health and Environmental Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption and Encourage Pro-environmental Behavioral Spillover
brief_description: daily message via automated private chat on Facebook Messenger about health environmental reasons to eat less RPM
outcome: 15-point response scale from 0 to 14 servings or more of red and processed meat (separately)
notes: NA

author: Alblas
title: “Meat” Me in the Middle: The Potential of a Social Norm Feedback Intervention in the Context of Meat Consumption – A Conceptual Replication
brief_description: message showing them “The results of last week show that the average meat consumption of Dutch residents was: 1.32 times per day.” In addition, participants in the descriptive norm only conditions received descriptive norm feedback: “Based on your answers, it appears that your meat consumption is above-/below- average compared to the average Dutch resident.” (but we didn't incldue that condition because the treatment is modified based on post-treatment data)
outcome: self-reported MAP consumption: "During the three weeks of data collection, participants were asked to report their meat consumption on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays."
notes: RCT issue (post-radomization bias): what treatment people get depends on their behaviors. Interesting study. there's a second treatment condition we didn't include because of post-treatment non-randomness. Some people in the injunctive norm get a frowny face if they are eating above average meat and a smiley face if they are doing better than average. But that's based on baseline covariate data gathered in the data collection process, so effectively there are *two* treatments, one with a positive mersage and one with a negative, but the negative or positive message isn't randomly assigned. Final note: the overall effect size for that condition was 0.01.

author: Alblas
title: “Meat” Me in the Middle: The Potential of a Social Norm Feedback Intervention in the Context of Meat Consumption – A Conceptual Replication
brief_description: you get a message about whether your meat consumption is above or below average for the population along witha. frowny face if you are above or a smiley face if you are below
outcome: self-reported MAP consumption: "During the three weeks of data collection, participants were asked to report their meat consumption on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays."
notes: RCT issue (post-RCT issue bias): what treatment people get depends on their behaviors. Interesting study. there's a second treatment condition we didn't include because of post-treatment non-randomness. Some people in the injunctive norm get a frowny face if they are eating above average meat and a smiley face if they are doing better than average. But that's based on baseline covariate data gathered in the data collection process, so effectively there are *two* treatments, one with a positive mersage and one with a negative, but the negative or positive message isn't randomly assigned. Final note: the overall effect size for that condition was 0.01.

author: Epperson
title: Information Avoidance and Moral Behavior: Experimental Evidence from Food Choices
brief_description: 360° video about the living conditions of pigs in intensive farming via a virtual reality (VR) headset combined with willingness to pay aspect (to avoid the film)
outcome: food purchases at Canteen
notes: RCT issue (not randomized): subjects have some ability to select into and out of treatment with willingness to pay variance. But treatment is still plausibly exogenous because of the random variation of the actual price point so it's borderline

author: Frie
title: Effectiveness of an Online Programme to Tackle Individual’s Meat Intake through SElf‑regulation (OPTIMISE): A randomised controlled trial
brief_description: Online Programme to Tackle Individual Meat Intake through SElf-regulation where participants choose strategies to cut back on meat consumption and then get daily reminders to implement those strategies and comparisons to their initial meat consumption
outcome: meat frequency questionnaire
notes: RCT issue (horse race design):  control "participants were asked to try to reduce their meat consumption during the following eight weeks with no further guidance")

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: putting vegetarian meals first (VegFirst) in a cafeteria setting with the non-veg option 181 cm behind in college B
outcome: proportion of vegetarian meals sold
notes: RCT issue (not randomized): Arguably the 'weekly' alteration is in the right ballpark but it's not really random. For the purposes of this robustness check we're looking at all the weekly alteration interventions, each as its own data point

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: putting vegetarian meals first (VegFirst) in a cafeteria setting with the non-veg option 85 cm behind in college A
outcome: proportion of vegetarian meals sold
notes: RCT issue (not randomized). Arguably the 'weekly' alteration is in the right ballpark but it's not really random. For the purposes of this robustness check we're looking at all the weekly alteration interventions, each as its own data point

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: putting vegetarian meals first (VegFirst) in a cafeteria setting with the non-veg option 85 cm behind in college B
outcome: proportion of vegetarian meals sold
notes: RCT issue (not randomized): Arguably the 'weekly' alteration is in the right ballpark but it's not really random. For the purposes of this robustness check we're looking at all the weekly alteration interventions, each as its own data point

author: Kaiser
title: Financial rewards for long-term environmental protection
brief_description: free vegetarian meals for a week (outcomes measured a week after that) at a German university cafeteria
outcome: self-reported proportion of vegetarian meals eaten
notes: RCT issue (procedural issue): p. 7 where they weren't sure how to account for 32 participants, which is about 10%, and the treatment groups are lopsided.

author: Loy
title: Supporting Sustainable Food Consumption: Mental Contrasting with Implementation Intentions (MCII) Aligns Intentions and Behavior
brief_description: mental contrasting with implementation intentions (MCII) wherepeople identify and imagine a desired future andcurrent obstacles standing in its way, then  address the obstacles with if-then plans specifying when, where, and how to act differently.
outcome: food diary (meat reduction in grams per day)
notes: RCT issue (horse race design): Control group receives information ("All participants read a text providing information about meat consumption...It not only addressed environmental consequences of meat consumption but also other arguments for reduced consumption...These further arguments referred to ethical, health, and social/political aspects of meat consumption including references to scientific publications") where treatment group also receives "mental contrasting with implementation intentions (MCII)" intervention. There's a third condition that was collected and presented in the first author's thesis but it will compare to the same control group

author: Piazza
title: Monitoring a meat-free pledge with smartphones: An experimental study
brief_description: recruited to take a pledge to do your best to stop eating meat for a month
outcome: self-reported meat consumption
notes: RCT issue (horse race design): (all participants received information about going meat free). A bit tricky to get a handle on the effect sizesbut the difference in the treatment group is B =0.01 and the difference in the control gruop is B = -0.01 so we're calling it an unspecified null of 0.01. The Ns are also ab it of a guess beacuse we don't know how many people were in each group (At all sites, the briefing sessions, which lasted approximately 30–40 min, were run with 2–8 participants to reduce the number of total sessions required...random assignment was applied to sessions")

author: Delichatsios
title: EatSmart: efficacy of a multifaceted preventive nutrition intervention in clinical practice
brief_description: (1) mailed personalized dietary recom- mendations and educational booklets focusing on fruits and vegetables, red m’eat, and dairy foods, tai- lored to patients’baseline intake and stage of readiness to change eating behaviors; (2) verbal endorsement by the primary care provider of the benefits of these rec- ommendations; and (3) two motivational counseling sessions with telephone counselors to set dietary goals.
outcome: weekly servings of red and/or processed meat
outcome_category: servings of red and processed meat per week
notes: underpowered (6 clusters). The SD is something back of the envelope based on the confidence intervals. The overall effect is an "Intent-to treat analysis adjusted for age, sex, race, and baseline value of the food intake."

author: Lentz
title: Meat consumption and potential reduction for environmental and public health benefits
brief_description: film sessions held in rented rooms within the School of Geography at the University of Otago where participants watched one of three videos advocating for eating less meat or a control video about Jim Carcey's performance as Andy Kaufman in 'Man on the Moon'
outcome: proportion saying they reduced their meat intake
notes: underpowered (about 21-22 subjects per arm). But actually a very nice design and of relevance to other forthcoming documentary studies

author: Lentz
title: Meat consumption and potential reduction for environmental and public health benefits
brief_description: film sessions held in rented rooms within the School of Geography at the University of Otago where participants watched one of three videos advocating for eating less meat or a control video about Jim Carcey's performance as Andy Kaufman in 'Man on the Moon'
outcome: proportion saying they reduced their meat intake
notes: underpowered (about 21-22 subjects per arm). But actually a very nice design and of relevance to other forthcoming documentary studies

author: Lentz
title: Meat consumption and potential reduction for environmental and public health benefits
brief_description: film sessions held in rented rooms within the School of Geography at the University of Otago where participants watched one of three videos advocating for eating less meat or a control video about Jim Carcey's performance as Andy Kaufman in 'Man on the Moon'
outcome: proportion saying they reduced their meat intake
notes: underpowered (about 21-22 subjects per arm). But actually a very nice design and of relevance to other forthcoming documentary studies

author: Reinders
title: Menu-engineering in restaurants - adapting portion sizes on plates to enhance vegetable consumption: a real-life experiment
brief_description: the vegetable portion sizes on the plates of main dishes were doubled (150 g of vegetables instead of 75 g) and the portion sizes of meat on the plates were reduced by an average of 12.5%.
outcome: grams of meat eaten
notes: underpowered (3 clusters) but still a nice study, worth summarising

author: Dannenberg
title: The effects of observability and an information nudge on food choice
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: survey in which university students are told that 60% of students in a survey are vegetarian/vegan and then 20% are given a private opportunity to select a voucher for a meal with meat or not
outcome: does the meal have meat or not
notes: no delay, but a strong study and shows clear backlash effects to being observed. Maybe annoyance with the blatantness of the experimental procedure? LIke the *clear* attempt to manipulate people into eating less meat (nudging them about the environmental consequences of meat and then telling them "your choice will be public.") By contrast,the nudge alone seems to produce reasonable effects. That, or there's just random variation and if you average all the treatment groups you get about the baseline effect. Noting that we found a 2023 preprint version of this paper but are taking stats from the published Food Policy article.

author: Dannenberg
title: The effects of observability and an information nudge on food choice
venue: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
brief_description: survey in which university students are told that 10% of students in a survey are vegetarian/vegan and then 20% are given an opportunity to select a voucher for a meal with meat or not but the results are public
outcome: does the meal have meat or not
notes: no delay, but a strong study and shows clear backlash effects to being observed. Maybe annoyance with the blatantness of the experimental procedure? LIke the *clear* attempt to manipulate people into eating less meat (nudging them about the environmental consequences of meat and then telling them "your choice will be public.") By contrast,the nudge alone seems to produce reasonable effects. That, or there's just random variation and if you average all the treatment groups you get about the baseline effect. Noting that we found a 2023 preprint version of this paper but are taking stats from the published Food Policy article.

outcome: does the meal have meat or not

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "“Did you know? On average, 44% of our canteen customers chose a vegan or vegetarian main dish during the last winter term."
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "Did you know? On average, 56% of our canteen customers chose a main dish containing meat or fish during the last winter term."
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "What do you think was the proportion of vegan or vegetarian main dishes sold in our canteen last winter term? ___% of the main dishes sold during the last winter term were vegan or vegetarian.”
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Griesoph
title: Guess What …?—How Guessed Norms Nudge Climate-Friendly Food Choices in Real-Life Settings
brief_description: survey with embedded statement: "What do you think was the proportion of meat and fish main dishes sold in our canteen last winter term? ___% of the main dishes sold during the last winter term contained meat, sausage or fish."
outcome: meal purchased at canteen
notes: no delay possible. I think the study takes place in Schleswig-Holstein based on the flyer they provide. The data for effect sizes comes form this paragraph on p. 7: "The share of selected vegan/vegetarian dishes was 62% in both control groups. For the meat descriptive norm and the vegetarian descriptive norm, we find a share of 57% vegan/vegetarian meal choices. Of the participants that received the meat guessed norm, 60% chose a vegan/vegetarian meal, while 64% in the vegetarian guessed norm group chose a vegan/vegetarian meal."

author: Hansen
title: Nudging healthy and sustainable food choices: three randomized controlled field experiments using a vegetarian lunch-default as a normative signal
brief_description: three conference registrations where participants sign up for a meal; the default is vegetarian or not
outcome: does the meal have meat or not
notes: no delay. It's actually a really interesting datapoint for talking about how traditional psych/behavioral science studies and these kinds of actual real world interventions can be hard to integrate. This one does have an effect, and it does have policy-relevant implications, as does Gravert 2019. It just doesn't show enduring effects (people might have a meat dish the next day to compensate or something).

author: Hansen
title: Nudging healthy and sustainable food choices: three randomized controlled field experiments using a vegetarian lunch-default as a normative signal

outcome: does the meal have meat or not

author: Sparkman
title: Dynamic Norms Promote Sustainable Behavior, Even if It Is Counternormative
brief_description: a survey which presents information about people who try to limit their meat consumption (static)
outcome: whether their meal has meat or not
notes: No delay. Takes places over multiple days but there is zero delay between treatment and any indiivdual meal choice. We have some other studies where a person is typically going to choose right away but there is at least some theoretical possibility that someone encounters the treatment on multiple days and therefore gets attenuated Stanford students.  edge case for place-based but I'm saying yes because "Café patrons waiting in line for lunch completed a survey- based intervention". Also, provides materials but not prergistration or open data: https://osf.io/yxf2t

author: Sparkman
title: Dynamic Norms Promote Sustainable Behavior, Even if It Is Counternormative
brief_description: a survey which presents information about people who are *changing* their behavior to  to limit their meat consumption (dynamic)
outcome: whether their meal has meat or not
notes: No delay. Takes places over multiple days but there is zero delay between treatment and any indiivdual meal choice. We have some other studies where a person is typically going to choose right away but there is at least some theoretical possibility that someone encounters the treatment on multiple days and therefore gets attenuated Stanford students.  edge case for place-based but I'm saying yes because "Café patrons waiting in line for lunch completed a survey- based intervention". Also, provides materials but not prergistration or open data: https://osf.io/yxf2t

author: Beresford
title: Low-fat dietary pattern and risk of colorectal cancer: the Women’s Health Initiative Randomized Controlled Dietary Modification Trial
brief_description: intensive behavioral modification pro- gram, using 18 group sessions in the first year and quarterly sessions there- after, led by specially trained and cer- tified nutritionists.
outcome: Red meat, medium servings/d
notes: encourages substitution to fish. This is a tough call, because it does show overall reductions (I calculated the effects before I understood that) but looking at the supplementary materials on the trial (https://sp.whi.org/researchers/studydoc/WHI%20and%20ES1%20Manual%20of%20Operations/1993-2005%20WHI%20CT%20and%20OS/Vol%202,%2006%20-%20Dietary%20Modification%20(DM).pdf), we see that part of the counseling was "Identify ways to increase fish consumption."

author: Celis-Morales
title: Effect of personalized nutrition on health-related behaviour change: evidence from the Food4Me European randomized controlled trial
brief_description: Personalized Nutrition (PN) program based on individual dietary intake data alone encouraging less intake of red meat and salt and saturated fat
outcome: grams of red meat
country: Ireland, The Netherlands, Spain, Greece, the UK, Poland, and Germany
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish): "Oily fish is full of essential omega-3 fatty acids - try to have 1 portion of oily fish per week" in the supplementary materials)

author: Celis-Morales
title: Effect of personalized nutrition on health-related behaviour change: evidence from the Food4Me European randomized controlled trial
brief_description: Personalized Nutrition (PN) program based on individual dietary intake and phenotypic data encouraging less intake of red meat and salt and saturated fat
outcome: grams of red meat
country: Ireland, The Netherlands, Spain, Greece, the UK, Poland, and Germany
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish): "Oily fish is full of essential omega-3 fatty acids - try to have 1 portion of oily fish per week" in the supplementary materials)

author: Celis-Morales
title: Effect of personalized nutrition on health-related behaviour change: evidence from the Food4Me European randomized controlled trial
brief_description: Personalized Nutrition (PN) program based on personalized dietary advice based on individual dietary intake and phenotypic and genotypic data encouraging less intake of red meat and salt and saturated fat
outcome: grams of red meat
country: Ireland, The Netherlands, Spain, Greece, the UK, Poland, and Germany
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish): "Oily fish is full of essential omega-3 fatty acids - try to have 1 portion of oily fish per week" in the supplementary materials)

author: Johansen
title: Changes in food habits and motivation for healthy eating among Pakistani women living in Norway: results from the InnvaDiab-DEPLAN study
brief_description: six sessions, each about 2 hours, on nutrition for Pakistani women living in Oslo
outcome: food frequency questionnaire (intake of red meats/week)
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish). a lot of the effect size is guesswork, I combined the chicken, red meat, and fish categories into one, and then estimated SD from a combination fo the p values (assuming from a t-test). But I think it's probably in the right ballpark

author: Matthews
title: Longitudinal effect of 20-year infancy-onset dietary intervention on food consumption and nutrient intake: the randomized controlled STRIP study
intervention_condition: Special Turku Coronary Risk Factor Intervention Project (STRIP)
brief_description: 30-minute individualized dietary counseling and nutrition education sessions led by a nutritionist...individualized in that the dietary counseling was based on the child’s diet as assessedthrough food records, and they addressed specific dietary questions and concerns of the families.
outcome: four day dietary recall
notes: encourages substitution (red meat to fish). again the SD numbers are a bit of a guess

author: Better Food Foundation
title: Serving up Plants by Default
brief_description: at three university cafeterias,
outcome: proportion of vegan meals sold
notes: other: not enough information to calculate the *net* effect size. as far as I can see, we're missing data on effects at the cafeteria overall, and a lot of people switched to other food stations). We can take the effect of treatment on the particular stations as a given and that's perhaps a biased estimate of the effect overall. The authors present an uncertainty bound where we assume that the decline in meals chosen on default days is entirely driven by people who go elsewhere and then choose meat., and then we get an effect of a relative reduction of  21.6%. But that's a lot of guesswork. A reader might find this problem less of a concern and take their estimate at face value, and if so, it's a very promsing result.

author: Bertolaso
title: Investigating the Effectiveness of Message Framing and Regulatory Fit in Increasing Positive Animal Attitude and Reducing Animal Products Consumption. A study for Animal Equality
brief_description: facebook ad for people looking to help Animal Equality improve its research leading to six facebook posts about "sows; mothers in loneliness and despair", "An investigation reveals the suffering of tuna",  "Do you know how pigs live in factory farms?", "the truth behind the egg industry: baby chicks ground up alive", "inside slaughterhouses",  and " one minute video revealing the process through which in the dairy industry newborn calves are systematically taken away from their mothers, along with [PROMOTION MESSAGE ] that places emphasis to expectations, accomplishments, and development needs; it depicts goals as ideals, and carries a strategic concern with approaching gains (presence of positives) and avoiding non-gains (absence of positives).
outcome: Animal Attitude Scale
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Bertolaso
title: Investigating the Effectiveness of Message Framing and Regulatory Fit in Increasing Positive Animal Attitude and Reducing Animal Products Consumption. A study for Animal Equality
brief_description: facebook ad for people looking to help Animal Equality improve its research leading to six facebook posts about "sows; mothers in loneliness and despair", "An investigation reveals the suffering of tuna",  "Do you know how pigs live in factory farms?", "the truth behind the egg industry: baby chicks ground up alive", "inside slaughterhouses",  and " one minute video revealing the process through which in the dairy industry newborn calves are systematically taken away from their mothers, along with prevention message telling them that they can save lives just by changing their diets. This was intended to highlight themes of "security, responsibility, and safety necessities, frames goals as obligations, and carries a strategic concern with approaching non-losses (absence of negatives) and avoiding losses (presence of negatives)."
outcome: Animal Attitude Scale
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Bertolaso
title: Investigating the Effectiveness of Message Framing and Regulatory Fit in Increasing Positive Animal Attitude and Reducing Animal Products Consumption. A study for Animal Equality
brief_description: facebook ad for people looking to help Animal Equality improve its research leading to six facebook posts about a cow who acts like a dog, a pig in a wheelchair, a chicken being dried with a hair dryer, a cute baby calf being fed by his caregiver, a video of a golden retriever behaving as a mother for a littler of baby chickens, and a video of fish who love to be petted, along with [PROMOTION MESSAGE ] that places "emphasis to expectations, accomplishments, and development needs; it depicts goals as ideals, and carries a strategic concern with approaching gains (presence of positives) and avoiding non-gains (absence of positives).
outcome: Animal Attitude Scale
notes: attitude for correlation check

This was intended to highlight themes of "security, responsibility, and safety necessities, frames goals as obligations, and carries a strategic concern with approaching non-losses (absence of negatives) and avoiding losses (presence of negatives)."

author: Fehrenbach
title: Designing Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption: A Test of the Extended Parallel Process Model
brief_description: watching a high threat/ high efficacy video on the dangers of meat consumption with guidelines for reducing meat consumption
outcome: Attitudes toward the  ecommended behaviors
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Fehrenbach
title: Designing Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption: A Test of the Extended Parallel Process Model
brief_description: watching a high threat/low efficacy video on the dangers of meat consumption
outcome: Attitudes toward the  ecommended behaviors
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Feltz
title: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies
brief_description: Participants read a philosophical ethics paper by the ethicist Mylan Engel (2002) that discussed the ethics of consuming animals for food. The focus of the paper was to argue that most people are already morally committed not to eat animals.
outcome: 4Ns scale consisting of "16 Likert-scale items (e.g., “It is normal to eat meat”) rated on a 7-point scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree)." lower numbers are more pro-animal welfare
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Feltz
title: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies
brief_description: Participants read a philosophical ethics paper by James Rachels (2017) that discussed the ethics of consuming animals for food. The focus of the paper was to elucidate a basic argument concerning animals that causing unnecessary pain is wrong and animals in factory farms experience unnecessary pain.
outcome: 4Ns scale consisting of "16 Likert-scale items (e.g., “It is normal to eat meat”) rated on a 7-point scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree)." lower numbers are more pro-animal welfare
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Feltz
title: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies
brief_description: Participants watched a short educational video about the conditions of factory farmed animals called “What Is Factory Farming? Us and the Planet.” The video was 145 seconds long and covered issues concerning treatment of factory farmed animals and the impacts of factory farming on the environment and human health.
outcome: 4Ns scale consisting of "16 Likert-scale items (e.g., “It is normal to eat meat”) rated on a 7-point scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree)." lower numbers are more pro-animal welfare
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Feltz
title: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies
brief_description: read an educational pamphlet about the conditions of factory farmed animals called “Compassionate Choices: If You Care about Animals, Please Consider not Eating Them.” The pamphlet was sixteen A5 sized pages discussing various aspects of factory farming, including the effects on the animals and human health. The pamphlet also included tips for reducing animal consumption including alternatives to animal products.
outcome: 4Ns scale consisting of "16 Likert-scale items (e.g., “It is normal to eat meat”) rated on a 7-point scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree)." lower numbers are more pro-animal welfare
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Weingarten
title: Can information influence meat consumption behaviour? An experimenta lfield study in the university canteen
brief_description: four paragraphs of information delivered online about meat consumption. First was about high meat consumption rates in Germany. Second and third were about health harms to meat consumption. The fourth recommended reducing meat consumption
outcome: semantic 5-point Bipolar scale and assessed different attitudinal features of meat consumption (e.g. “I think, eating less meat in the canteen would be…” 1 =bad, 5 =good).
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Weingarten
title: Can information influence meat consumption behaviour? An experimenta lfield study in the university canteen
brief_description: four paragraphs of information delivered online about meat consumption. First was about high meat consumption rates in Germany. Second and third were about environmental harms to meat consumption. The fourth recommended reducing meat consumption
outcome: semantic 5-point Bipolar scale and assessed different attitudinal features of meat consumption (e.g. “I think, eating less meat in the canteen would be…” 1 =bad, 5 =good).
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Hennessy
title: The impact of information on animal product consumption
brief_description: factual leaflets modeled after those used by animal advocacy organizations worldwide, including " pictures of vegetarian celebrities in the why-focused leaflet to demonstrate a social norm"
outcome: Belief in Animal Mind Questionnaire -- I believe it’s important to treat cows humanely
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Mathur
title: Effectiveness of a Theory-Informed Documentary to Reduce Consumption of Meat and Animal Products: Three Randomized Controlled Experiments
brief_description: 20-minute documentary (Good For Us) produced by The Humane League
outcome: Importance of animal welfare
notes: attitude for correlation check

author: Mathur
title: Effectiveness of a Theory-Informed Documentary to Reduce Consumption of Meat and Animal Products: Three Randomized Controlled Experiments
brief_description: 20-minute documentary (Good For Us) produced by The Humane League
outcome: Importance of animal welfare

author: Bianchi
title: Replacing meat with alternative plant-based products (RE-MAP): a randomized controlled trial of a multicomponent behavioral intervention to reduce meat consumption
venue: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition
intervention_condition: four weeks of free meat substitutes and information and recipes
brief_description: multi-part intervention comprising free meat substitutes for the household for 4 weeks, information about health and environmental reasons to reduce, recipes, and success stories about people who ate less meat
outcome: Attitudes towards eating a low-meat diet
notes: attitude for correlation check
